title: Quality Quotes # 2
description: A quote from Chapter 1 of Zamm. Open the Doors!

transcript_parts.text: welcome to quality quotes in which I
read a quote from the work of the great
Robert M Pierce ik and discuss how its
wisdom can help us live a better life
today's quote is from Chapter one of zen
and the art of motorcycle maintenance
[Music]
[Applause]
these roads are truly different from the
main ones the whole piece of life and
personality of the people who live along
them are different they're not going
anywhere they're not too busy to be
courteous the hereness and nowness of
things is something they all know about
it's the others the ones who've moved to
the cities years ago and they're lost
offspring who have all but forgotten it
the discovery was real find I've
wondered why it took us so long to catch
on
we saw it and yet we didn't see it or
rather we were trained not to see it
calmed perhaps into thinking that the
real action was metropolitan and all
this was was just boring hinterland it
was a puzzling thing the truth knocks on
the door and you say go away I'm looking
for the truth and so it goes away
puzzling well much of rural America's
fallen into disrepair and dysfunction
due to lack of industry and influx of
opioids there are still small towns
across this country that have this
feeling about them the pace is different
I know I live part of the week in one of
these challenge these attributes that
Pierce of describes still exist there is
the hare nests and nowness about life in
which you don't get that sense of
impatience with interactions with people
that they are just getting through what
they have to say to you so that they can
get what they need from you and move on
to the next thing
they are courteous they live here
they're staying here and they are
contempt now all that's left is to live
life as well as possible without the
need of neurotically striving for
fortune and prestige there is a chronic
condition in our country today which
infected urban areas and has gotten much
worse the symptoms are the beliefs that
higher education equates with superior
intelligence that virtue simile
weights with virtue that religion is
superstition and that any difference of
opinion on these matters constitutes
ignorance and malevolence I can attest
for a long time that I had this disease
the disease of elitism and we the elites
are conned brainwashed into believing
this propaganda about ourselves and our
lifestyle of urban sophistication and
moral superiority what the serves to do
is sequester us into what Peirce had
called a cultural immune system where
we've got a wall around us and there is
no door for anyone or anything to come
in and anything that keeps us locked
into a system in which change in which
dynamism can't enter it is low quality
this low quality translates into a
complete and utter cluelessness about
other modes of understanding and living
some of which are high quality indeed
worse it turns our fellow man into
enemies for no reason whatsoever let me
give you an example how many
professional motorcycle mechanics do you
know that went to Harvard or any other
University for that matter that whole
mechanical way of understanding that
craftsmanship that very engaging with
the physical nature of reality you are
unlikely to find within this wall of
elitism where we live in our heads
working with one's hands is primarily
the domain of the non elite let's say so
what's the antidote for this disease for
me three books helped a lot the first is
an older one by Joe bagent deer-hunting
with Jesus in which a hippy returns to
the town of his birth Winchester
Virginia and seeks to understand its
residence and let us know what we're
doing wrong the second is hillbilly
elegy very similar book but most
importantly is Jonathan heights
righteous mind this last one should be
required reading on how to get out from
behind whatever wall or bubble is
keeping you from understanding your
compatriots also another thing you could
do why don't you get to know your
mechanic now let's go back to something
Pearson said about these folks they
operate with a hereness and now
what does this remind you of well the
first thing I thought of was this is the
eastern approach the folks that Pearson
referred to already have this nowness
built into their way of being as they
say Zen is nothing special
this quote contains one of those great
lines that most people remember even
after the first reading the truth knocks
at the door and you said go away I'm
looking for the truth
and so it goes away I think it is the
truth of peace of mind that city
dwellers lack with this constant
striving unconsciously they know it's
missing
thus the mindfulness revolution thus the
pop Buddhism craze but almost like they
can't help themselves Satori becomes an
object of pursuit these urban
sophisticates have met the buddha on the
road and welcomed him with open arms
drew peace of mind is knocking saying
please open the door this Buddha they
send away so the theme here is open
those doors for quality existence the
one holding in the system and the one
keeping out the truth so I hope that
made sense and I will see you next week
for another quality quote
